skos:definition.@value: Gist is a minimalist upper ontology created by Semantic Arts
An agreement having a balance, as in a bank account, or credit card account, or Accounts Receivable account.
A device that can affect the real world via a message interface
A reference to a place (real or virtual) that can be located by some routing algorithm, and where messages or things can be sent to or retrieved from. E.g. PO Box or URL to a PDF file.
Something which two or more People or Organizations mutually commit to do.
A measurement of two-dimensional space.
A unit of two-dimensional area, such as square inches or hectares.
An intentional, person-made thing, which could be physical or content
A very general term for the characteristic of something that is being measured.  E.g., property (height) or a process (cycle time) or a behavior (loyalty).
An amount decremented or incremented by a series of transactions.

A primitive unit that cannot be decomposed into other units. It can be converted from one measurement system to another.  The base units in gist are the seven primitive units from the System Internationale (SI): (meter, second, kilogram, ampere, kelvin, mole, candela), plus three convenience ones: each. bit and usDollar.
A way of categorizing events.  E.g., differentiating drilling versus cutting.
A man-made structure for dwelling or working.
An address to which you can send mail, or that you could find in the physical world.
Any combination of descriptions of things offered together.  Could be a kit (several parts offered together), but could also be a product plus a warranty.
A description of a product or service to be delivered, given in a sufficient level of detail that a receiver could determine whether delivery constituted discharge of the obligation to deliver.

skos:scopeNote.@value: In short, an unambiguous characterization of what it is that a potential buyer is paying for.

skos:definition.@value: A concept or label used to categorize other instances informally. Things that can be thought of as types are usually Categories.

skos:example.@value: Tags used in folksonomies; formal definitions from other systems.

skos:scopeNote.@value: Often a 'bucket' can be modeled either as an owl:Class or as a gist:Category. Use the latter if you don't care much about the formal structure of the different types, or if there is a whole hierarchy of types that are going to be managed by a group separate from the ontology developers. The formal structure may be defined elsewhere and linked to, if necessary.

skos:definition.@value: A ratio unit whose numerator and denominator reduce to 1
A ratio unit whose numerator and denominator reduce to 1
A unit that is expressed in units that have no conversions.  It may be a simple unit.  It may also be a product or ratio unit that bottoms out in simple units.

skos:example.@value: A simple unit: kilogram
The standard unit for acceleration is meters per square second (feet per square second  requires a conversion)

skos:scopeNote.@value: Coherent unit is the physics term for this, informally you might think of it as the standard unit for a given dimension.
In principle, the CoherentUnit for a ProductUnit or RatioUnit can be inferred by recursively decomposing the products and ratios into their respective CoherentUnits, bottoming out in SimpleUnits

skos:definition.@value: Any identifiable grouping of instances.  For instance, a jury is a collection of people.

skos:example.@value: A jury is a group of people,   a financial ledger is a collection of transaction entries; a route is an (ordered) collection of segments.

skos:definition.@value: An obligation (possibly unilateral).

A component is an artifact that contributes to a system.  Could be a simple mechanical component, such as the float contributing to the toilet tank maintaining a constant level, or much more complex as in the internet of things.
An event that actually started after the present time.  When we record an end time it ceases to be contemporaneous

skos:scopeNote.@value: All contemporaneous events eventually end and, due to the nature of the open world, we can never be sure that a contemporaneous event hasn't ended. As a result, this is really a contemporaneous and historical event.

skos:definition.@value: A document, program, image, etc.  (Categories are not content until they are written down.)
Intellectual Property reduced to text, audio etc.  If it contains text (written or spoken), it may be in a language.
An event with a probability of happening in the future, and usually dependent upon some other event or condition.
An obligation that is not yet firm.  There is some contingent event, the occurrence of which will cause the obligation to become firm.

skos:scopeNote.@value: A contingent obligation might have a getter counterparty (as in the case of insurance); but it might not (as in the case of an offer).

skos:definition.@value: An Agreement which can be enforced by law
A specification of some aspect of a contract.
A collection of terms approved and managed by some organization or person.
A device that takes messages or signals from a sensor and decides through algorithms whether and which actuator to fire via messages
A kind of controller.
A measure that involves countable amounts (?eaches? as well as cases, etc.). Can be decimal.

skos:scopeNote.@value: Count is not disjoint with all the other magnitudes, as there are some magnitudes that could conceivably be counted.

skos:definition.@value: A unit of counting, especially ?each?, but also units such as dozens.
The geopolitical body that governs a geopolitical region recognized as a country.
A unit of money. Note: this is the only unit whose conversion factors include time (i.e., the conversion rates change on a daily basis).
A unit to measure amounts of digital information.
A point in time known only to the accuracy of one day.  Say the signing of the declaration of independence on 7/4/1776
The difficulty of reversing a commitment.

skos:example.@value: A car rental typically has a lower degree of commitment than an airfare reservation.

skos:definition.@value: A unit to measure linear distance, such as feet or kilometers.
Time, but not on a timeline.

skos:example.@value: One week (or seven days), but not Jan 1, 2008 to Jan 7, 2008 (which is an interval).

skos:scopeNote.@value: Intervals have durations, but are not themselves durations.

skos:definition.@value: A unit to measure passage of time: hours, days, years.
A flow of electric charge.
Unit of electrical current, which is charge per unit time.  The SI unit is the ampere.  (Note that electrical current is a composed unit.)
Any place an electronic message (email, fax, etc.) can be sent.
An email address is a unique identifier for an email account. It is used to both send and receive email messages over the Internet.
Tangible property other than land or buildings.  Any kind of equipment, could be machine, router, car etc.
Categories of equipment
Something happening over some period of time, often characterized as some kind of activity being carried out by some person, organization, or software application.
A measure of distance, which could be distances over the Earth, and could also be height, width, length, depth, girth, etc.
Content which is in a particular format. (E.g., HTML, PDF, JPG.)
A function is what a specific made item is intended to do.  For instance: transmit electricity, provide ballast, control ambient temperature.
The real-world media type for content.

skos:example.@value: Audio, still image, video, textual, physical (e.g., a statue), or performance (i.e. a play).  Or it could be oil or pastel for a painting.

skos:definition.@value: An individual point on the Earth's surface, identified by latitude, longitude and altitude. If altitude is missing, it is assumed to be at the Earth's surface.  However, altitude is measured from sea level.  these points are to the WGS-84 coordinate system using the GPS decimal lat/long

skos:scopeNote.@value: Assume coordinate system used by Google (WGS 84 Web Mercator).

skos:definition.@value: A collection of GeoRegions that are being administered by a Government Organization
A bounded region (or set of regions) on the surface of the Earth.

skos:example.@value: The bounded shape that defines the region occupied by Crater Lake; the bounded area known as the contiguous USA.

skos:scopeNote.@value: A GeoRegion could be non-contiguous; e.g. the region governed by the USA is the region governed by the lower 48 states plus that of Alaska and Hawaii.  Child classes in lower ontologies can make this distinction.
A GeoRegion has an area, but it is not itself an instance of the Area class.  (Area in gist is a magnitude).

skos:definition.@value: An ordered set of GeoPoints that defines a path from starting point to ending point.
A single portion of a GeoRegion which has been divided (i.e., segmented).
A three-dimensional space on or near the surface of the Earth, such as an oil reservoir, the body of a lake, or an airspace.
A specific intentional endpoint.  One can tell whether it has been achieved, as opposed to an intention, which may not have an evaluation function.

An organization established either by fiat (as a conquering army overtakes a land and declares a government) or by delegation from a fiat government, such as a state or local government or a specific agency. Differs from a corporation in that it cannot be owned.

skos:example.@value: The State of Washington Office of Financial Management; the Food and Drug Administration; the Scottish Parliament.

skos:scopeNote.@value: Establishment by a CountryGovernment may be indirect via local, regional, or national GovernmentOrganization(s) that ultimately are recognized by a CountryGovernment.

skos:definition.@value: By default time instants are expressed in Greenwich, if you need to be explicit (to calculate offset for instance)
A collection of People. The group may or may not be an Organization.  Many organizations consist of groups of people, but that is not a defining characteristic.
An event which occurred in time, with an actual end earlier than the present moment.
A point in time known only to the accuracy of one minute.  For things like calendar appointments and time reporting
Content that is used to uniquely identify something or someone.

skos:example.@value: SSN for a person; serial number for a product; employee ID.

skos:scopeNote.@value: This is used in conjunction with gist:identifiedBy

skos:definition.@value: An amount of data, such as 6 petabytes, or 640KB.
A work, invention or concept, independent of its being expressed in text, audio, video, image, or live performance.  IP can also be tacit knowledge, know-how, or skill. Also includes Brands.

skos:example.@value: The Old Man and The Sea; the Page Rank algorithm; Coca Cola

skos:scopeNote.@value: For literature this could be called the ?Work?, except that ?work? is a highly overloaded term (expenditure of energy, resource consumption, art).  Often the first expression precedes our recognition of the IP, but subsequent expressions are known to be derivatives of the IP, even if they are expression-to-expression translations (or copies).

skos:definition.@value: Goal, desire, aspiration. This is the "teleologic" aspect of the system that indicates things are done with a purpose.
Something permanently attached to the Earth.
A recognized, organized set of symbols and grammar.

skos:example.@value: Natural languages such as English and Spanish; computer languages such as OWL, Python, and XML.

skos:definition.@value: Something that is now, or at some point in time was, alive and growing.

skos:example.@value: A cat, a mushroom, a tree.
Negative examples: fictional life forms such as Unicorns or Mickey Mouse.

skos:scopeNote.@value: In the open world, you must assume that it might have since died.

skos:definition.@value: A point in time expressed relative to a local time zone. Can be converted to Universal Time using the time zone offset. The precision is used to state how precise this instant is.  Typical values would be day, hour, minute or second.

A measure of the wavelength-weighted power emitted by a light source in a particular direction per unit solid angle.  This is based on the luminosity function, a standardized model of the sensitivity of the human eye.
The measure of brightness. The SI unit is the candela.
Base class for units which can be converted.  The primitive units can be converted from one measurement system to another; the complex units (ratio or product) have to decompose to their primitives.

skos:scopeNote.@value: Magnitudes of the same dimensional type (i.e., duration or electric current) can be compared with a greater-than or less-than operator, but can still differ in their relationToTheWorld type.  (I.e., you can compare actuals to estimates or references, so long as the dimension is the same.)
The precision should be in the same type of unit as the magnitude.

skos:definition.@value: Magnitude of mass.
A unit representing the amount of matter in a particle or object.  The SI unit of mass is the kilogram.
A physicality on which a work could be implemented or exposed. E.g., paper, clay, or a computer monitor.
A specific instance of content sent from an Organization, Person, or Application to at least one other Organization, Person, or Application.

skos:example.@value: An email message, a phone call, a voice message, or a Web Service message.

skos:definition.@value: Each pulse from a Sensor is reflected in a message, as well as each instruction to an Actuator
A digitized type that computer applications can recognize.
Amount of a substance, as counted molecules.
Amount of chemical material.  Measured in Avogadro units (moles) of 6.02 x 10^23 molecules.
A special type of magnitude, due to the way rounding is handled in math and the temporal aspect of conversion.
A network is a connected set of links and nodes
A link in a network.  This is the abstraction of the network.  The physical instantiation couple be pipes, or wire  but may also be non physical such as wireless networks or organization structures
A node in a network.  Note the network is the abstract representation of the network.  It is physically instantiated with equipment, or in some cases People.
A future commitment from one organization or person to another. Contracts are sets of obligations to do or forbear, or to indemnify or warrant.

skos:scopeNote.@value: Obligations will often be governed by some Agreement or Offer.

skos:definition.@value: A commitment to buy or sell a described or identified part or service.
A collection where the members are in a fixed sequence.
An Ordered Collection where no item can be of the same rank as any other item.  In mathematical terms, this is a ?strict total order?.
A member of an Ordinal Collection.  It necessarily precedes or is preceded by another Ordinal Member in the same collection. (This last condition cannot be formally stated in OWL).
A generic organization that can be formal or informal, legal or non-legal. It can have members, or not.

skos:example.@value: Legal entities like companies; non-legal entities like clubs, committees, or departments.

skos:scopeNote.@value: There are a plethora of different kinds of organizations that differ along many facets, including members, structure, purpose, legal vs. non-legal, etc.

skos:definition.@value: A ratio where the numerator and denominator are of the same unit of measure.

skos:scopeNote.@value: There are various ways to represent percentage: 50/100 could be represented as ?50? or ?0.5?.  gist uses the latter, as it involves fewer conversions for subsequent use.

skos:definition.@value: A description of things one is permitted to do. This could be broad, such as free speech, but more often is very specific, such as the right of egress through a particular property.
A human being that may or may not still be alive.

skos:example.@value: Negative example:fictional characters.

skos:definition.@value: The things that a sensor can sense, such as light, heat, current, moisture, etc.
The effects to be realized in the real world, such as lifting a garage door, turning off a valve, dropping cadmium rods, etc.
An event that can be said to have occurred at some place in space.

skos:example.@value: A meeting, a car accident.
Negative examples: Excludes events that have no meaningful location, such as financial events or project milestones.

skos:definition.@value: You could, at least in principle, put an RFID tag on members of this class. Physical things are made of something.  E.g., statues are made of bronze.

skos:example.@value: A computer, a book.
Negative example: A discontinuous thing like a manufacturing line cannot reasonably have an RFID attached to it, even though its parts are not the same kind of thing as the whole.

skos:scopeNote.@value: In practice, this always means that the parts are not the same kind of thing as the whole.

skos:definition.@value: Non corporeal material, i.e. 'stuff' which can be divided into parts where each part retains its essence.

skos:example.@value: An amount of water, of penicillin, of sand, of gold. An actual piece of gold, not gold the concept.

skos:scopeNote.@value: An instance of this class must be a physical thing, and not just a categorical description.
Some things are substances at a macro level, but ultimately end up as not being divisible into the same kind of thing.  E.g. sand vs. grains of sand., bacteria vs. an individual bacterium.

skos:definition.@value: Union of all the geo classes
An event which, at the time it is created, is to occur in the future.
A set of codes the postal authorities can use to deliver physical mail.

skos:example.@value: A street address, a PO Box, an FPO code, or the route codes.

skos:definition.@value: Any of many ways of categorizing products, including models, NATO product codes, and the like.
A magnitude expressed as a product of primitives.  (E.g., Force = M*A).
Offering something which could be physically warehoused or digitally stored.
A unit of measure that is the product of two simpler ones.

skos:example.@value: Area and Volume are the classic cases.  But other, more exotic cases exist, such as Newtons.

skos:definition.@value: A project is a task (usually a longer duration task) made up of other tasks.
This is a number whose unit of measure is a ratio.

skos:example.@value: Speed.  The ratio magnitude is 60, the unit of measure might be MilesPerHour.

skos:scopeNote.@value: A RatioMagnitude just has one decimal value.

skos:definition.@value: A UnitOfMeasure composed of a numerator unit and a denominator unit.

skos:example.@value: Miles per hour.

skos:scopeNote.@value: If needed, a conversion factor for a RatioUnit can be (recursively) derived from the conversion factors of the numerator and denominator units.  E.g., the derived conversion factor from km/minute to meters/second is 1000/60 or 16 2/3.

skos:definition.@value: A measure that was neither measured nor estimated but set by fiat. For instance, a goal. There is no Measurement associated with a ReferenceValue.
Content which has been expressed, either to print, or through speakers, or on a monitor.

A documented physical or functional need that a particular design, product, or process must be able to perform.  Alternately, the obligation of a person or organization to behave in a certain way (i.e., drive on the right side of the road).
A description of things one is prevented from doing.  Most laws are restrictions.
A task planned to occur.  When it was scheduled, it would have been in the future, but now might be in the past.
Superclass for all types of metadata, including owl concepts (such as class) and relational (tables, elements) and tool related (queries, R2RML maps etc etc)
A device that can detect something and report it. Light sensors, temperature sensors,
A description of something that can be done for a person or organization (which produces some form of an act).

Each simple unit has a base unit and a conversion factor to the base. The bases are from the System International (SI). The conversion factor is the number which one multiplies a Unit by to get to base, or divides by to get from base.  E.g., the convertToBase for inch is 0.0254 to get to the base unit (meter).
A set of requirements to be satisfied by a material, design, product, or service.
A system is an artifact with component parts where the parts contribute to the goal of the system
A point in time known to the accuracy of a millisecond.  For posting transaction recorded on times
This is for folksonomy type terms, which can be made up on the fly by users.
A task which has been defined and either scheduled or accomplished, or both.
An outline of a task of a particular type, that will, when instantiated, generate an actual (unscheduled) task.
A controlled vocabulary arranged as a hierarchy of concepts.
A numeric code a telephonic device uses for contacting another telephonic device.

skos:example.@value: Mobile, fax, or landline phone number.

skos:definition.@value: The degree or intensity of heat present in a substance or object, especially as expressed according to a comparative scale.
Unit of measurement for expressing temperature.  Per SI, the base of temperature is in Kelvin, to allow for all units to be expressed relative to a real (in this case absolute) zero.

Something used to make instances in its own image.  In manufacturing this would be specialized as a die to make stamped parts, cookie cutters are templates for cookies, and forms are templates for data.

skos:example.@value: A form. A filled-in form has the structure of the form with data entered into some or all of the fields.

skos:scopeNote.@value: Use gist:basedOn to link the instantiation of a template back to its Template.

skos:definition.@value: A relationship existing for a period of time.

skos:example.@value: employs-Employment, hasStreetAddress-EstablishedLocation. One important context for reifying a property.

skos:scopeNote.@value: A temporal relation must be gist:connectedTo a minimum of two objects. For example, a temporal relation representing a period of employment is connected both to the person and to the role/position they held.

skos:definition.@value: Content expressed as words and numbers (not graphics).
All time instants are Greenwich and the local equal universal.

skos:example.@value: A literal instant (as in 12:01.0001 January 1, 2008), or a broader but still single point in time (January 1, 2008). In the latter case, we are declaring a time instant to be an interval with no duration (or really a duration only equal to its precision).

skos:scopeNote.@value: Our identity criteria require that something refers to each Time Instant instance.

skos:definition.@value: A region that observes a uniform standard time for legal, commercial, and social purposes.  A typical time zone averages 15? of longitude in width and typically observes a clock time one hour earlier than the zone immediately to the east.
The algorithm for getting from Greenwich Mean Time to local time, which includes the time zone offset and rules about daylight savings time.
An event which has an effect on at least one accumulator.
Standard unit by which we measure things
Three-dimensional space, or equivalent fluid measurement.
Units of three-dimensional space, expressed here as an area times a distance.
A bit (short for binary digit) is the smallest unit of data in a computer. A bit has a single binary value, either 0 or 1.
Subject matter of a document.
The types of input messages that will be allowed
When something did occur, therefore noting an historical event.
When something did end, therefore noting an historical event.
When something did start, therefore noting an historical event.
Where the effect came from
The subject has or had or will have an effect on the object
Connection between an ID and the thing that minted the ID.  It may be a person or organization, or could be an algorithm (next available or random number generator)
The intention (say a grant) allows a particular kind of activity (for instance egress)
What this aspect is referring to
Pointer to the thing something was derived from
Reason for an event
Points to a taxonomy item or other less formally defined class.
A way to categorize a behavior.
Whose address is this
The subject conforms to the Object, e.g. meet an obligation, meet terms of an offer, adhere to a specification
A non-owning, non-causal, non-subordinate (i.e., peer-to-peer) relationship.
Links to the string corresponding to Text
The parts of a system contribute to the goal/ function of the whole system

Add this number to get to the zero point.  On the Celsius scale, the conversionOffset is -273.15 degrees C. On the Fahrenheit scale it is -459.67 degrees.  Is equal to 0 when the unit has the same zero point as the base unit. e.g. inch, meter.

The conversion factor used to get to the base unit.  E.g., multiplying by 0.0254 gets you from inches to meters. Divide by this number to go the other way. Used in conjunction with conversionOffset to convert from one unit to another. Degrees K =  (Degrees F - conversionOffset) * convertToBase. Or K = (F-(-469.67)) * (5/9.  To go the other way: F = (K * 9/5) -469.67.  Try it on Google.

Note this kind of conversion will only work with temperatures if they are in Kelvin or Rankine (with a true 0).  You multiply to get to the base, divide to go from the base. mph to mps is .44704.  The multiple from kph to mps is .277778 .  To convert 60 mph to kph is (60 * .44704 / .277778 or 96.56056 kph
The actual value of a magnitude.
Relates a RatioUnit such as meters/second to the denominator Unit (e.g. second).
Document the subject matter appeared in
A statement about someone or something's attributes or characteristics.

skos:example.@value: The Empire State Building is a 102-story Art Deco skyscraper in Midtown Manhattan in New York City, United States. It was designed by Shreve, Lamb & Harmon and built from 1930 to 1931.

skos:scopeNote.@value: This property is used to provide a description of an instance entity in greater detail than a label.

skos:definition.@value: The relationship between a part and a whole where the part has independent existence.

skos:scopeNote.@value: It is safest to use this property when there is semantic directness inherent in the relationship, rather than choosing appropriate granularity. For example, a spark plug is a direct part of an engine block; there cannot be any intermediate parts.  Beware of making a directPartOf assertion and then inserting an intermediate part; this will result in making an asserted triple false even though there was no change in the world.
Use this property to directly associate a part with the whole. partOf is the transitive version.

skos:definition.@value: Immediate parent task
Inverse of directly precedes

skos:scopeNote.@value: It is safest to use this property only when the directness has a semantic correspondence with the world. Only break a direct link by inserting an intermediate item when that change corresponds to a change in the world.

skos:definition.@value: A generic ordering relation indicating that the Subject comes immediately before the Object.

skos:scopeNote.@value: It is safest to use this property only when the directness has a semantic correspondence with the world. Only break a direct link by inserting an intermediate item when that change corresponds to a change in the world.

skos:definition.@value: The party doing the recognition
The set of actuators that a controller can affect
Links to the string corresponding to EncryptedText
Connects the subject to its end time.
Seconds since 1/1/1970 UTC (unix time )
The language something was expressed in
The party that is the source of something (e.g. a message, shipment, etc.)

skos:scopeNote.@value: This is not the inverse of toAgent. A message can be to someone. If we made it the inverse the person would be "from" the message

skos:definition.@value: Origin
Relates one place to another place that contains the first.
Relate one place to another place that is contained within the first.
What is in the location
A thing occupies are region
A reference from the thing being governed to the governor
The subject controls or inhibits the object in some way
Distance above sea level
Relates a UnitOfMeasure to its BaseUnit.  This indicates what kind of Unit something is.

skos:example.@value: Saying that a furlong hasBaseUnit  meter says it is a DistanceUnit.

skos:definition.@value: Date a living thing is or will be born.

skos:editorialNote.@value: For 10.0.0 release: This property will be a subproperty of gist:start, rather than gist:actualStart (as currently), to acknowledge the fact that the birth may not yet have occurred. In this case, the birthdate is expected although not known. [Change this note to a skos:scopeNote.]

skos:definition.@value: Points to a general class of places you can send messages including postal addresses, fax numbers, phone numbers, email, web site, etc.
Date a living thing died
The relationship between a whole and a part where the part has independent existence.

skos:scopeNote.@value: It is safest to use this property when there is semantic directness inherent in the relationship, rather than choosing appropriate granularity. For example, a spark plug is a direct part of an engine block; there cannot be any intermediate parts.  Beware of making a hasDirectPart assertion and then inserting an intermediate part; this will result in making an asserted triple false even though there was no change in the world.
No cascading delete.
Use this property to directly associate a part with the whole. hasPart is the transitive version.

skos:definition.@value: The subject category is a supercategory of the object category. This property defines the direct links in a category hierarchy; no intermediate categories can exist between the direct links.

skos:scopeNote.@value: Unlike its superproperty gist:hasSubCategory, this property is not transitive. It is essentially the same as the non-transitive skos:narrower, using gist:Category rather than skos:Concept.

skos:definition.@value: Immediate child task
The subject category is a subcategory of the object category. This property defines the direct links in a category hierarchy; no intermediate categories can exist between the direct links.

skos:scopeNote.@value: Unlike its superproperty gist:hasSuperCategory, this property is not transitive. It is essentially the same as the non-transitive skos:broader, using gist:Category rather than skos:Concept.

skos:definition.@value: The connections at the abstract level of a network.  Note this is directed but the parent is the undirected version
The recipient
The active party, the one with the obligation or the one initiating the transfer
The reason for doing something
What equipment or person is currently in this node.  Note to create a temporal view make a TemporalRelation for this property
When laws and contracts are meted out
To have a comparable numerical value. Each magnitude has a unit.
Relates a Collection to its member individuals.
Used for informal hierarchical taxonomies.  Supports polyhierarchies
Used for informal hierarchical taxonomies.  Supports polyhierarchies
An inverse functional version of hasMember to ensure that no OrderedMember can be in more than one OrderedCollection., which can quickly lead to problems.
The transitive version of hasDirectPart
Relates something (e.g. an agreement) to things that play a role, or take part or are otherwise involved in some way.

skos:example.@value: An event of transferring money has a participating account that receives the money.

skos:scopeNote.@value: The thing with participants will often be an agreement, event or obligation.
This is intended as an abstract property. Only its subproperties will be directly used.

skos:definition.@value: The people or organizations participating in an event, agreement or obligation

skos:example.@value: For loan agreements, one might create hasLender and hasBorrower as subproperties of hasParty.

skos:definition.@value: Where something is located

Links a Magnitude to the degree of accuracy of the numeric value.   This allows for fuzzy numbers.  All magnitudes have a precision.  Usually we don't record them.  When we do this, it will be a value whose extent covers 2 standard deviations around the stated magnitude

skos:example.@value: Temperature precise to tenth of a degree C; TimeInstant precise to 24 hours.

skos:scopeNote.@value: Most frequently apples to Magnitude(s) and TimeInstant. Could also apply to a measurement.

skos:definition.@value: For a complex unit refers to a unit that has all the component parts in SI
A place that can be found on a map, has geo coordinates; you could live or work there.
The subject category is inclusive of, or broader than, the object category. Everything categorized by the subcategory can be inferred to be categorized by the supercategory.

skos:scopeNote.@value: This is essentially the same as skos:narrowerTransitive, using gist:Category instead of skos:Concept.

skos:definition.@value: A task that is part of a larger task. The time frame of the subtasks may overlap but may not extend beyond the time frame of the parent task. A subtask may be part of more than one parent task.
The subject category is included by, or narrower than, the object category. Everything categorized by the subcategory can be inferred to be categorized by the supercategory.

skos:scopeNote.@value: This is essentially the same as skos:broaderTransitive, using gist:Category instead of skos:Concept.

skos:definition.@value: Used for folksonomy style categories (non controlled vocabulary)
The connections at the abstract level of a network. Note this is directed but the parent is the undirected version
Used for taxos that must have single parents
Used for taxos that must have single parents
Which unit of measure you are using. All measures are expressed in some unit of measure, even if we don't know what it is initially.
This is like a URI: a thing can have more than one ID, but each of the IDs must refer to a unique thing.
The thing the identifier refers to.
Date that something was modified.
Degrees above or below equator
An annotation for providing the licensing on this or derivative ontologies
Relates a TimeInstant to a string indicating what the local date is.
Relates a TimeInstant to an xsd:dateTime literal representing the local date and time.
Relates a TimeInstant to a string indicating what the local time is.
Degrees from GM
Relates something to the the substance that it is made up of.

skos:example.@value: The vase is made up of clay

skos:definition.@value: What group the member is in
Relates a ProductUnit such as square mile to the second of two units multiplied together (e.g. mile).
Relates a ProductUnit such as square mile to the first of two units multiplied together (e.g. mile)
Relates an individual to a casual name.

skos:scopeNote.@value: For more formal use, consider using a sub property of the object property, identifiedBy.

skos:definition.@value: Abstract connection for when connections are undirected
Relates a RatioUnit such as meter(s)/second to the numerator Unit (e.g. meter).
The geospatial place where something happened or will happen
How many hours the time zone is off GMT
Biological offspring
An inverse of hasOrderedMember
Possessing and controlling.  Ultimate form of ownership is the right to destroy.  Long list of potential Range classes
Biological Parent
The transitive version of directPartOf
What is in the fixed location
To be in a fixed position on the earth
Dates that were in the future at the time they were made.
A date/time that was at least at some point in time in the future. It may be in the past now, but when we planned it, it was in the future.

skos:scopeNote.@value: Most frequently apples to Event(s) and Offer(s). E.g. a conference or sale offer.

skos:definition.@value: A date/time that was at least at some point in time in the future. It may be in the past now, but when we planned it, it was in the future.
A generic ordering relation indicating that the Subject has the same order as or comes before the Object. The 'greater than or equal to' symbol is often used for this relation.
The intention (say a law) is intended to prevent this kind of behavior (say jay-walking)
The subject creates the object.

skos:example.@value: A task produces a deliverable.

skos:definition.@value: The entity that formally acknowledges the existence of, as the State recognizes the existence of a particular company
Recognizes

Date that something was posted, not necessarily the date it occurred. Must be after the occurred date, but could be before or after the planned date. (Unusual, but I could record today that I expected to be paid last week.)
What media something was rendered On
An intention that sets out a state of satisfaction (you are required to drive on right side of the road)
The set of sensors that a controller is attached to
We can have two local time instants refer to the same time, the same universal time.
For ordering ordered lists.
Connects the subject to its start time.
Whose street address is this
All the upper tasks this task belongs to
the "time zone" with Daylight Savings adjust
The party that is the recipient of something (e.g. a message, shipment, etc.)

skos:scopeNote.@value: This is not the inverse of fromAgent. A message can be from someone. If we made it the inverse the person would be "to" the message

skos:definition.@value: Destination

General causal relation.  For obligations a property that describes what would happen to trigger the contingent obligation.  In most cases, before the Contingent becomes an Obligation, the triggered by event is a planned event (that is it hasn't happened yet -- if it had happened the contingency would no longer be contingent.  In most cases it will be  a ContingentEvent .  Other uses include controls, processes etc
This is used for the actual value of a key or ID where you don't want the possibility of having more than one.
The standard symbol for the unit NOT using any special characters.  E.g. square meter would be m^2 rather than m?.

The standard symbol for the unit in HTML format for  pretty printing, may use special characters.  E.g. to show square meter as  m? rather than m^2, the value of this property would be "m²" This is for when Unicode not supported and the display will be HTML format.
The standard symbol for the unit preferred for pretty printing, may use special characters.  E.g. square meter would be  m? rather than m^2.
Relates a TimeInstant to a string indicating what the universal date is.
Relates a TimeInstant to an xsd:dateTime literal representing the universal time.
Relates a TimeInstant to a string indicating what the universal time is.
The area over which the sensor can sense (might be a small geospatial area or a specific wire in a circuit)
